title: SFO Offers Barclays Deal Amid Qatar Probe
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Jul 21, 2015, 12:52 BST - UK Markets close in 3 hrs 38 mins SFO Offers Barclays Deal Amid Qatar Probe By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 1 hour 10 minutes ago View Photo 

Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) has been asked to sign a deferred prosecution agreement (DPA) in the latest twist to a long-running Serious Fraud Office probe into the bank’s fundraisings during the 2008 financial crisis. 
Sky News has learnt that the agency wrote to Barclays several weeks ago to propose the deal, according to people close to the situation. 
It was unclear on Tuesday whether Barclays had provided a formal response to the SFO, although insiders suggested that some bank directors were lukewarm about the idea of signing a DPA. 
News of the latest chapter in the SFO’s three-year-long investigation comes just a fortnight after Barclays ousted Antony Jenkins, the chief executive who was appointed in 2012 to rehabilitate the company’s reputation. 
The SFO gained powers to strike DPAs in February last year, and has yet to sign the first such deal, which would enable the signatory to avoid prosecution while adhering to a series of strict conditions. 
Barclays was party to a separate DPA with American regulators when it became the first bank to admit its role in the Libor rate-rigging scandal in 2012. 
Sources say the SFO recently opened discussions about a number of possible DPAs, which by law can only be signed with companies rather than individuals. 
The SFO has also been investigating a number of former Barclays executives, including John Varley and Chris Lucas, respectively the chief executive and finance director at the time of the capital-raisings from Qatari investors in June and October 2008. 
Barclays raised billions of pounds during the course of that year from private investors, while rivals such as Lloyds Banking Group and Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) were forced to rely on taxpayer bail-outs. 
Barclays subsequently argued that its avoidance of direct state support should enable it to remain free from restrictions on pay and dividends which applied to its Government-backed competitors. 
In its latest annual report, Barclays repeated earlier disclosures that the SFO – along with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) and several US authorities – was continuing to investigate the arrangements with Qatar Holding LLC. 
“The existence of the advisory services agreement entered into in June 2008 was disclosed but the entry into the advisory services agreement in October 2008 and the fees payable under both agreements, which amount to a total of £322m payable over a period of five years, were not disclosed,” Barclays said. 
“While the Warning Notices [issued by the FCA] consider that [Barclays] believed at the time that there should be at least some unspecified and undetermined value to be derived from the agreements, they state that the primary purpose of the agreements was not to obtain advisory services but to make additional payments, which would not be disclosed, for the Qatari participation in the capital-raisings.” 
The FCA has imposed a £50m fine on Barclays in relation to alleged breaches of its disclosure obligations, which the bank is contesting. 
The City watchdog has agreed to delay the remainder of its enforcement process until after the SFO’s investigation is completed. 
Last year, David Green, the SFO’s director, explained its decision to adopt DPAs as part of its armoury for pursuing corporate crime. 
"At present, when a company is convicted of a criminal offence, a court can impose a fine or put it out of business by winding it up. 
"Both these outcomes can cause collateral damage to employees and shareholders who may be blameless,” he said. 
"[DPAs] avoid that collateral damage and provide a welcome addition to the prosecutor's tool kit for use in appropriate circumstances." 
Mr Green insisted that DPAs were not “a panacea, nor are they a mechanism for a corporate offender to buy itself out of trouble”. 
Barclays and the SFO both declined to comment.
